item.title: Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age - Hindustan Times
item.description:
7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age

Publication Date: December 20, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

As we age, keeping our memory sharp can become a challenge. Harvard University has provided seven tips to help individuals maintain and enhance their memory regardless of their age.

  • Keep Learning: Engaging in continuous education can help keep the brain active.
  • Use All Your Senses: Involve multiple senses during learning for better retention.
  • Believe in Yourself: Positive self-belief can aid memory improvement.
  • Economize Your Brain Use: Organize everyday items to avoid cluttering your memory.
  • Repeat What You Want to Know: Reinforce memory by repeating information aloud or in writing.
  • Space It Out: Use spaced repetition at intervals to enhance memory retention.
  • Make a Mnemonic: Use creative mnemonics for easier recall of information.
"Engaging the whole brain through varied learning strategies enhances memory retention."

By incorporating these tips into daily routines, individuals can enhance their cognitive ability and maintain sharper memories as they age.

item.title: Health expert shares top 10 morning habits to include in your routine for a productive day - The Indian Express
item.description:
Health expert shares top 10 morning habits to include in your routine for a productive day

Published on: December 20, 2024 by Indian Express

The article discusses ten essential morning habits recommended by health expert Karan Bhargava to enhance productivity and well-being as we approach 2025.

  • Wake Up at Your Optimal Time
  • Hydrate Immediately
  • Engage in Physical Activity
  • Practice Mindfulness or Meditation
  • Plan Your Day
  • Eat a Nutritious Breakfast
  • Avoid the Snooze Button
  • Limit Early Screen Time
  • Practice Gratitude
  • Tackle the Most Important Task First
“Incorporating these habits into your morning routine can create a structured and positive start to your day, enhancing productivity and overall well-being.” - Karan Bhargava

Adopting these habits can significantly impact your daily performance and set the tone for a successful day ahead.

item.title: Winter and joint pain: Why it gets worse in cold weather - The Times of India
item.description:
Winter and Joint Pain: Why It Gets Worse in Cold Weather

Published on: October 2023 | Source: Health News

As temperatures drop, many individuals experience exacerbated joint pain. This article explores the reasons behind this seasonal phenomenon.

  • Cold weather can lead to a decrease in body temperature, which may trigger pain in joint areas.
  • Low humidity levels in winter can also affect the body's natural lubrication of joints.
  • Many people tend to stay inactive during colder months, which can exacerbate stiffness and pain.
  • It is important to maintain a healthy lifestyle and consider low-impact exercises to alleviate symptoms.
“Understanding how cold weather affects your joints can help manage pain effectively.”

It is crucial for individuals with joint pain to adopt strategies that mitigate discomfort during winter months.

item.title: Fertility specialist on fertility in your 20s, 30s, and 40s: How the chances of conception change - The Times of India
item.description:
Fertility specialist on fertility in your 20s, 30s, and 40s: How the chances of conception change

Publication Date: Not specified, Source: Not specified

This article discusses how fertility changes across different age groups, examining conception chances in the 20s, 30s, and 40s.

  • Fertility typically peaks in the 20s and begins to decline in the 30s.
  • Factors influencing fertility include overall health, lifestyle choices, and medical history.
  • Assisted reproductive technologies may provide options for women in their 30s and 40s.
  • Emotional and psychological impacts of fertility concerns are significant for individuals.
"Understanding your fertility can empower your decisions regarding family planning."

This article highlights the importance of awareness around fertility and encourages individuals to consult fertility specialists for personalized guidance.

item.title: Why do Indians suffer from vitamin D deficiency despite plenty of sunlight? | Increasing use of sunscreen also a reason | Inshorts - Inshorts
item.description:
Why do Indians suffer from vitamin D deficiency despite plenty of sunlight?

Published on: Saturday 21 December, 2024 at 05:17 pm | Source: Inshorts

Despite living in a tropical climate, many Indians suffer from a lack of vitamin D. Factors such as indoor lifestyles, cultural clothing practices, and pollution contribute to this deficiency.

  • Many urban Indians spend a majority of their time indoors.
  • Cultural practices that cover most of the body limit sun exposure.
  • High levels of dust and pollution block UVB rays, further reducing vitamin D synthesis.
"Most people in urban areas spend...majority...time indoors," explained Dr. Minesh Mehta, Consultant Emergency Medicine.

This highlights a significant health issue where the expected sunlight exposure does not translate to adequate vitamin D levels for the population.

item.title: Mental Health Revolution: How Gratitude and Tech Will Redefine Wellness in 2025 - Times Now
item.description:
Mental Health Revolution: How Gratitude and Tech Will Redefine Wellness in 2025

Publication Date: October 2023
Source: Times Now

The mental health landscape is evolving, with 2025 promising groundbreaking advancements blending technology with timeless practices centered on gratitude.

  • Gratitude serves as a foundation for sustainable mental health practices.
  • Technology such as AI-driven therapy tools enhances mental health care accessibility.
  • Neurofeedback techniques combined with gratitude practices enhance emotional regulation.
  • Gratitude journaling apps will integrate AI prompts to reinforce positivity.
  • Holistic therapies like sound therapy and affirmations will become mainstream.
  • Community gratitude circles will gain momentum for collective healing.
“Visualisation techniques combined with brainwave monitoring allow individuals to reinforce positive neural pathways.” - Aashmeen Munjaal

As 2025 unfolds, mental health innovations combined with gratitude education will reshape approaches to well-being, making healing more accessible and impactful.

item.title: Sugar restrictions in early life could reduce the risk of diabetes later: Study - The Times of India
item.description:
Sugar restrictions in early life could reduce the risk of diabetes later: Study

Publication Date: [Date unavailable] Source: [Source unavailable]

This study suggests that limiting sugar intake in early childhood could significantly lower the risk of developing diabetes later in life.

  • Early intervention in sugar consumption is crucial.
  • The findings indicate a potential public health strategy to combat rising diabetes rates.
  • Additional research is needed to validate these findings.
"Restricting sugar is essential in shaping future health patterns in children's lives."

In summary, addressing sugar consumption early could play a pivotal role in preventing diabetes.

item.title: Ilness caused by respiratory viruses increases in USA - The Times of India
item.description:
Illness Caused by Respiratory Viruses Increases in USA

Publication Date: N/A | Source: N/A

Recent reports indicate a significant rise in illnesses caused by respiratory viruses across the United States, raising concerns about public health and safety.

  • The incidence of respiratory infections has notably increased in several states.
  • Health officials are monitoring trends and preparing resources to combat this rise.
  • Public awareness campaigns are being implemented to educate people on prevention measures.
"We are seeing an alarming trend that requires immediate attention from both healthcare providers and the public." - Health Official

In conclusion, the increase in respiratory illnesses necessitates a collective response to safeguard public health.

item.title: A fentanyl antidote is saving lives - but isn't ending the fentanyl crisis - Hindustan Times
item.description:
A fentanyl antidote is saving lives - but isn't ending the fentanyl crisis

Date: December 18, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses the life-saving role of naloxone, an antidote for fentanyl overdoses, while highlighting that the fentanyl crisis in the U.S. continues unabated. Despite a drop in overdose deaths, challenges remain.

  • Naloxone availability has significantly decreased overdose deaths in the U.S. and Ohio, contributing to a 22% reduction in deaths nationwide.
  • Fentanyl remains cheaply available, perpetuating the crisis.
  • Mixing tranq drugs with fentanyl may be a factor in the declining fatality rates, as these drugs are less deadly and extend the high.
  • Overdoses in Ohio have led to increased visits to support centers, even as naloxone saves lives.
  • Experts warn that despite the decline in deaths, the number of substance abusers continues to rise.
“And that scares me to death,” says Scott Sanders, executive director of the Hope Resource Center. “Because all the powers that be are going to be throwing parties. Like, wow, look, it's not a problem anymore.”

Although naloxone has saved many lives, the article emphasizes that ongoing issues in communities plagued by fentanyl addiction signal that the crisis is far from resolved.

item.title: Journal finally retracts the discredited hydroxychloroquine paper - The Hindu
item.description:
Journal Finally Retracts Discredited Hydroxychloroquine Study

Published Date: December 21, 2024

Source: The Hindu

The study by Didier Raoult and colleagues, published in March 2020, claimed hydroxychloroquine was effective against COVID-19. This paper has now been retracted due to serious ethical concerns.

  • The controversial study was published with inadequate peer review.
  • ICMR approved hydroxychloroquine for prophylaxis shortly after publication, which led to significant global demand.
  • The FDA initially granted emergency use authorization for the drug but revoked it a month and a half later.
  • The journal expressed concerns three days after publication but only retracted the paper recently.
  • Authors of the paper later requested to withdraw their association due to concerns over the study’s results.
“The article does not meet the Society’s expected standard.” - ISAC Statement

This retraction emphasizes the importance of rigorous peer review and ethical standards in clinical research.

item.title: Winter wellness guide: Tips for staying healthy and strong amid seasonal challenges - The Times of India
item.description:
Winter Wellness Guide: Tips for Staying Healthy and Strong Amid Seasonal Challenges

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

This article offers essential tips for maintaining health and wellness during the challenging winter season, highlighting the increase in respiratory infections and the importance of immunity, food hygiene, and exercise.

  • Winter is associated with a rise in respiratory infections, particularly among vulnerable groups.
  • Key preventive measures include protection against environmental factors, improving respiratory immunity, and practicing good food hygiene.
  • Regular physical activity and vaccinations are important for enhancing immunity.
  • Food safety is crucial to prevent infections like Typhoid, especially for those eating out frequently.
“If we had no winter, the spring would not be so pleasant: if we did not sometimes taste of adversity, prosperity would not be so welcome.” – Anne Bradstreet

By implementing these strategies, individuals can better navigate the winter months and enhance their overall health.

item.title: Does 2022 H5N1 bind, replicate better in the respiratory tract? - The Hindu
item.description:
H5N1 Virus Shows Increased Binding and Replication in Human Respiratory Tract

Published Date: December 21, 2024Source: The Hindu

The 2022 H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b virus has demonstrated enhanced attachment and replication capabilities in the human respiratory tract. Although the fatality rate remains high at 52%, no deaths have been reported among the 64 confirmed human cases in the U.S. as of December 20, 2024.

  • 64 confirmed H5N1 cases in the U.S. including 34 in California.
  • The first reported case was in Texas in April 2024.
  • Most cases have been mild; however, one severe case reported in Louisiana.
  • The current H5N1 variant shows improved binding to human respiratory cells compared to the 2005 strain.
  • Study suggests potential for increased human infection risk with ongoing H5N1 viruses.
“Our data show abundant attachment of 2022 H5N1 virus to upper and lower respiratory tract tissues, which contrasts with 2005 H5N1 virus.”

The findings of the study indicate a concerning trajectory for H5N1 viruses, necessitating ongoing monitoring of human infections and potential adaptations of the virus.

item.title: First-Ever Blood-Stage Vaccine For Malaria Shows Promising Results In Phase IIb Trial - Times Now
item.description:
First-Ever Blood-Stage Vaccine For Malaria Shows Promising Results In Phase IIb Trial

Publication Date: 2023, Source: The Lancet Infectious Diseases

The RH5.1/Matrix-M blood-stage malaria vaccine has shown promising results in a Phase IIb trial, potentially offering significant protection for populations at high risk of malaria infection.

  • The trial involved 361 children aged 5 to 17 months across Burkina Faso and the UK.
  • RH5.1/Matrix-M demonstrated 55% efficacy against clinical malaria and 80% efficacy in reducing malaria parasites in the bloodstream.
  • It targets the blood stage of malaria, complementing existing pre-erythrocytic vaccines.
  • The urgency for malaria vaccines is highlighted by approximately 263 million cases and 597,000 deaths reported in 2023, mostly in Africa.
“RH5.1/Matrix-M has the potential to be the first blood-stage malaria vaccine brought to market. This could be a much-needed addition to the currently available malaria vaccines.” - Stephanie Kurdach, GlobalData

The development of effective vaccines like RH5.1/Matrix-M represents a crucial step forward in malaria prevention, particularly for vulnerable populations.

item.title: Bird Flu Spreads in Animals, but Human Risk Remains Low: WHO - Nagaland Post
item.description:
Bird Flu Spreads in Animals, but Human Risk Remains Low: WHO

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Nagaland Post

The World Health Organization (WHO) has assessed the global public health risk from the H5N1 bird flu virus as currently low, despite a recent increase in human cases.

  • 76 human infections reported in 2024, mainly among US farm workers.
  • Risk remains low due to no sustained human-to-human transmission.
  • Warnings about the virus's potential for rapid adaptation.
  • Concerns for occupationally exposed groups in contact with infected animals.
  • Significant economic and ecological concerns due to the virus's impact on poultry and wildlife.
“The potential for rapid adaptation emphasizes the ongoing risk to occupationally exposed groups.”

Continued vigilance and international collaboration are essential to manage the risks associated with the H5N1 bird flu virus.

item.title: Recognizing Severe Malaria In Children: Critical Signs And Emergency Response - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Recognizing Severe Malaria In Children: Critical Signs And Emergency Response

Publication Date: October 2024 Source: The Health Site

Malaria continues to plague the world, particularly affecting children in India as the monsoon season prompts an increase in cases. The young are more vulnerable, necessitating rapid recognition of severe symptoms.

Key Points:

  • Malaria cases are rising among children due to monsoon-related mosquito breeding.
  • Severe symptoms in children can include persistent high fever, respiratory distress, and signs of cerebral malaria.
  • Immediate medical intervention with antimalarial drugs and supportive care is crucial for recovery.
  • Preventive measures are vital for safeguarding against malaria, particularly for high-risk populations.
“Protecting your child from malaria is about safeguarding not only their health but also their future.”

The role of healthcare providers and parents is critical in recognizing and responding to severe malaria, contributing to the fight against the disease.

item.title: Flesh-Eating Ulcer Warning Issued in Australia as Cases Rise - Nagaland Post
item.description:
Flesh-Eating Ulcer Warning Issued in Australia as Cases Rise

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Nagaland Post

Australian health authorities in Victoria have issued a warning about a rise in Buruli ulcer cases, a flesh-eating bacterial infection believed to spread from possums to humans via mosquitoes.

The infection, which initially presents as a painless lump or wound that can develop into a destructive ulcer, poses a risk of permanent disfigurement and disability if left untreated.

  • 344 confirmed infections in 2024.
  • Infection not person-to-person transmissible.
  • Preventative measures recommended: avoid mosquito bites, early diagnosis and treatment.
“Early diagnosis and treatment can minimize damage.”

This warning underscores the importance of being vigilant during warmer months and taking precautions against mosquito bites to protect against this serious health risk.

item.title: Think Sattu is desi protein powder? Nutritionist reveals the shocking reality of popular protein alternatives - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Popular protein foods in reality are barely meeting the protein requirements. Nutritionist lists them out.

Date: Dec 21, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

This article reveals surprising truths about popular protein alternatives in Indian diets, highlighting how many are misguided about the protein content in foods like sattu, dal, and chia seeds.

  • Many believe common foods like sattu and dal provide high protein, but they fall short of daily requirements.
  • Sattu contains only 5-7 grams of protein per glass.
  • Dal provides around 4-5 grams of protein per katori.
  • Mushrooms contain only 3 grams of protein per 100 grams.
  • Peanut butter is high in calories and fat, offering just 10 grams of protein per 2 tablespoons.
  • Quinoa and millet offer similar protein to wheat, which is about 13 grams per 100 grams.
  • Protein bars typically have more sugar than protein.
“Most Indians believe that one katori (bowl) dal is good enough to meet their requirements, but one katori doesn't have more than four to five gms of protein.” - Mohita Mascarenhas

The nutritionist advises that while these foods can contribute small amounts of protein, they should not be relied upon as the sole protein sources in one’s diet.

item.title: Virus causing gut infections could play role in development of Alzheimer’s: Study - The Indian Express
item.description:
Virus causing gut infections could play role in development of Alzheimer’s: Study

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: Indian Express

A recent study reveals that a virus causing gut infections may play a significant role in the development of Alzheimer's disease. Researchers suggest existing antiviral drugs could be repurposed to treat or prevent this form of the disease.

  • The herpes-causing virus can remain active in the gut and travel to the brain through the vagus nerve.
  • Once in the brain, the virus alters the immune response, contributing to Alzheimer’s disease pathology.
  • Research indicates that this virus subtype may affect 25-45% of Alzheimer’s patients.
  • Antibodies specific to the virus were found in the spinal fluid of Alzheimer’s patients.
  • The presence of the herpes virus has been linked to the activation of specific immune cells involved in Alzheimer’s disease.
“We think we’ve identified a biologically unique subtype of Alzheimer’s that may affect 25-45% of people with the disease,” said Ben Readhead, first author and research associate professor at Arizona State University.

This study opens avenues for further exploration into the relationship between gut health and neurodegenerative diseases, potentially reshaping our understanding of Alzheimer's disease pathology.
